Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: The Community Paralegal Model and Access to Justice

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration: Access to justice and legal empowerment interventions can be crucial for states to combat violence and poverty and for ordinary people to address a range of socioeconomic challenges. This project will explore the rise of the community paralegal model as a means of increasing access to justice and legal empowerment. As this study will examine successful donor-civil society legal empowerment partnerships, it will be relevant to scholars and policymakers interested in how site-specific legal knowledge is created and the politics of how the community paralegal model are put into practice. <br/><br/>This research will employ historical and archival research of primary and secondary sources to trace the creation of community paralegal organizations, their organizational histories and features, and changes to the legal and political frameworks in which they operate. Interviews and participant observation will be conducted with community paralegals, authorities, and stakeholders. This project will examine the political, historical, and social context of paralegal work, how paralegals reshape understandings of law, and how that paralegal work reverberates throughout relevant policy arenas over time.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In the modern international landscape, government and civil society groups increasingly acknowledge that formal legal systems cannot fully address systemic violence and poverty. Furthermore, the law is not the only way for people to remedy critical problems of work, housing, health, and family life that affect their everyday lives. The goal of this project was to understand how experimental policy interventions that do not rely on lawyers generate local interpretations of law, which in turn create new forms of cooperation and resistance among civil society, governments, and international aid donors. Specifically, the Co-PI (K. Frazier) investigated the role of community paralegals in South Africa, one of the oldest recognized models for non-lawyer legal and social assistance in the world. Similar programs across the Global South, and increasingly the United States and Europe, have been modeled off of the South African experience. Community paralegals are typically trained in various aspects of state law, human rights, and dispute resolution and operate independently from law firms or legal aid offices. While they provide legal advice and accompaniment to courts and police stations, more often they act as community organizers, social activists, and liaisons to various state institutions. The project asked, beyond helping individual clients in communities, what long-term political role do community paralegals play in shaping understandings of law, justice, and democratic participation? How do these ideas move among local, national, and international networks? Do new patterns of cooperation and resistance emerge among the state, civil society, and the international donors that fund these projects?

Because of the Covid-19 pandemic, K. Frazier conducted one year of remote fieldwork and seven months of on-site fieldwork in South Africa between September 2020 and April 2023. Research methods included interviews and participant observations with more than 100 community paralegals, government officials, legal professionals, community members, donor agency staff, and policy experts. The project also utilized three archives in South Africa and two digital archives for historical analysis of community paralegal programs as they relate to wider anti-apartheid, pro-democracy, and human rights movements.

The project?s findings illuminate that the work of community paralegals ? both internationally and within South Africa ? have always been closely tied to political and social movements focused on state-building. Lay people helping mediate disputes or provide social assistance is not a new phenomenon globally. However, creating new organizations or networks that respond to the failure of state courts and lawyers has gone hand-in-hand with the continued growth of the nation-state in the twentieth and twenty-first centuries. Whether it is helping people access newly fomented rights, such as voting or access to social welfare, or resist oppressive regimes, like the pass laws in apartheid South Africa or Jim Crow laws in the U.S., networks like those of community paralegals in South Africa have helped communities navigate the different ways the state looms large in their lives. Specifically, there was a rise in this type of policy intervention in the post-WWII era as the social welfare state expanded in the Global North, as decolonization occurred across the Global South, and as bodies of international law were created to enumerate further rights in light of authoritarian regimes and protracted conflict.

Furthermore, this project highlights that, even though they operate as grassroots actors in local communities, community paralegals share expertise and build legitimacy through complex regional, national, and transnational networks. Historically there has been deep exchange with civil rights activists in the U.S. and similar groups across Africa. While the work they has been critical to holding the state accountable across different time periods in South Africa, it has also been used by international actors (such as aid donors) to build out an international vision, such as formulating a new UN instrument, to solidify the role of community paralegals within the scope of rule of law work.

To date, the research has produced two conference papers (currently in revision for peer-reviewed journal submission). These conferences included a global audience of academics and practitioners concerned with questions of access to justice and how to create effective non-lawyer programs. There are tentative plans to disseminate the results in Spring 2024 to relevant institutions in South Africa as well as during the annual meeting of the Law and Society Association (an international law and social sciences academic association). The dissertation project will be completed in summer 2024.
